'''Lovie Lee''' (March 17, 1909 – May 23, 1997)<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Jason Ankeny |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lovie-lee-mn0000299819/biography |title=Lovie Lee | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} These are various birth years cited for Lee, including 1917 and 1923</ref><ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1996.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1996 - 1997 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] [[pianist]] and [[singing|singer]]. He is best known for his work accompanying [[Muddy Waters]],<ref name="Dead"/> although he did record a solo album in 1992. He was the 'adoptive stepfather' of fellow bluesman, [[Carey Bell]], and thus 'grandfather' to [[Lurrie Bell]].

==Biography==
He was born '''Edward Lee Watson''' in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]], [[United States]].<ref name="AMG"/> Lee grew up in [[Meridian, Mississippi]], and was self taught on the piano, utilising his skills in various churches, and playing at [[rodeo]]s and [[vaudeville]].<ref name="Pearson"/> He had already acquired his [[nickname]], 'Lovie', from a doting aunt.<ref name="Jazz"/> He found part time employment playing with the Swinging Cats in the early 1950s.  The outfit included Carey Bell, who Lee took under his 'fatherly' protection, and they jointly relocated to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] in September 1956.<ref name="Pearson">{{cite book
| first= Barry Lee
| last= Pearson
| year= 2005
| title= Jook right on: blues stories and blues storytellers
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[University of Tennessee Press]] 
| location= [[Knoxville, Tennessee]]
| isbn= 1-57233-432-0
| page= 208}}</ref><ref name="Jazz"/> Lee worked during the day in a woodworking factory, and for many years played in the evening in numerous Chicago blues [[nightclub]]s, including Porter's Lounge.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Jazz">{{cite web |url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/musician.php?id=8658 |title=Lovie Lee |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Allaboutjazz.com |accessdate=December 8, 2011}}</ref> He was well known around Chicago for his blues piano playing.<ref name="AMG"/> Lee later worked as an upholsterer, but kept together his backing band, known as the Sensationals.<ref name="Jazz"/>

After he retired from full-time day work, Lee joined [[Muddy Waters]] band in 1979, replacing [[Pinetop Perkins]] on the piano stool.<ref name="Pearson"/> He was recommended to Muddy Waters by [[George "Mojo" Buford]], after Lee had worked with Buford in [[North Dakota]]. Lee stayed in situ until Muddy's death in 1983, and then returned to playing in Chicago clubs.<ref name="Jazz"/>

Lee made some private recordings in both 1984 and 1989, and this work plus later contemporary tracks, were released as the [[album]] ''Good Candy'' (1992).<ref name="AMG"/>  His recording utilised musicians such as [[Eddie Taylor]], [[Odie Payne]], plus both Carey and Lurrie Bell.<ref name="Album"/> 

Lee died in Chicago in May 1997.<ref name="Dead"/>
